awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF: The Influence of Particle Phase Morphology on the Hygroscopic Behavior of Atmospheric Aerosols
awd_abstract_narration:
This Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (PRF) supports studies to investigate the factors that influence the uptake of water by small particles in the atmosphere. Factors that may be important include temperature, relative humidity, and particle phase morphologies, such as whether a particle may be a mixture of solids, semi-solids, and/or liquids, or may have various surface coatings. These factors influence particle growth and the formation of clouds in the atmosphere. Hence this research is important for understanding how atmospheric aerosols influence climate.

The scientific questions that this research addresses include the following: (1) What role does particle phase morphology play in the activation and growth of cloud condensation nuclei; (2) Is there evidence of complex particle phase behavior in the natural atmosphere; and (3) How well do current state-of- the-art thermodynamic and kinetic models capture the complex relationship between particle phase and water vapor uptake? Laboratory and field measurements will be coupled with data from thermodynamic and kinetic models to accomplish the objectives of the research. Most of this research will take place in the Linde and Robinson Laboratory chamber facility at the California Institute of Technology.

por.por_cntn:
Atmospheric aerosols, small liquid or solid particles suspended in the atmosphere, can be derived from both natural and anthropogenic sources and influence climate, air quality, and human health. The amount of water present in atmospheric aerosols, and the efficiency with which these particles serve as the sites on which cloud droplets form, affects the extent to which these particles scatter solar radiation, influencing their impacts on visibility and climate. In fact, interactions between atmospheric aerosols and water vapor remain one of the largest sources of uncertainty regarding the influence of atmospheric aerosols on climate. A deeper understanding of the ways in which aerosol particle properties influence their water-uptake behavior is needed in order to reduce this uncertainty. Notably, recent work has indicated that under some circumstances, two separate liquid phases can be present in a single particle – similar to water and oil separation effects. This effect is termed liquid-liquid phase separation. In addition, some particle components can be highly viscous or even glassy. The prevalence of these phenomena, or “complex phase behaviors,” is dependent on several factors, including the chemical composition of the particles and ambient conditions such as temperature and relative humidity. Utilizing a combination of laboratory experiments, computer modeling, and measurements conducted in the ambient atmosphere, this research project systematically explored the influence of complex particle phase behaviors on aerosol water-uptake properties.

The results of this work demonstrated that the prevalence of liquid-liquid phase separation and/or high-viscosity particle components has a significant impact on aerosol water-uptake behavior. For aerosols studied here that were comprised of chemical components that undergo liquid-liquid phase separation at low to moderate relative humidities, water uptake at those relative humidities was lower than would be expected assuming that the particles were present as well-mixed liquids (as is assumed in the majority of computer models of atmospheric aerosol behavior). On the other hand, for aerosols systems that contained viscous components, rapid drying of the particles increased particle viscosity, causing the particles to retain more water than would be expected if the particles were present as low-viscosity liquids. We also observed that particles containing polymer-like compounds that maintain a liquid-liquid phase separation morphology up to high relative humidities were very efficient nucleation sites for the formation of cloud droplets. Combined, this work helps to explain the factors influencing the water-uptake behavior of atmospheric aerosols that have been observed previously in field campaigns and will also aid in improving the representation of atmospheric aerosols in climate and atmospheric computer models.

Finally, this project funded a unique field campaign in which the water-uptake properties of atmospheric aerosols associated with emissions from a large algal bloom off of the coast of Central California were measured. We observed that the efficiency with which these particles served as nucleation sites for the formation of cloud droplets was higher than for particles that were measured previously in the same region, but in the absence of this algal bloom. It has been hypothesized that the presence of biopolymers and biosurfactants in marine aerosols derived from biologically-active waters contributes to this behavior. These components are similar to the polymer-like chemical components we studied in the lab as described above. Because the timing and magnitude of the major algal bloom can partially be attributed to anomalously high sea surface temperatures, and conditions like this may increase in frequency, intensity, and/or duration in a changing climate, this work provides insight into the factors that may influence marine cloud properties in a changing climate. As a whole, this research project contributes to the widespread effort to reduce uncertainty regarding the influence of atmospheric aerosols on climate. This is key to improving forecasts of changes in the climate system, which, in turn, is crucial to the development of climate risk mitigation and adaptation strategies.
